Title: How to prove $(1+1/x)^x$ is increasing when $x>0$?
Content: Let $F(x)=(1+\frac{1}{x})^x$. How do we prove $F(x)$ is increasing when $x>0$?
AcceptedAnswer:
Let $h(x) = \mathrm e^{-1/(1+x)}(1+1/x)$ and note that for $x > 0$,
$$
h(x) = \mathrm e^{-1/(1+x)}\cdot\frac{x+1}{x} > \left(1-\frac{1}{1+x}\right)\frac{x+1}{x} = 1.
$$ Now, let $g(x) = \log F(x)$ and note that 
$$
g'(x) = \log(1+1/x) - \frac{1}{1+x} = \log h(x) > \log 1 = 0\>,
$$
and so we are done.
